so_18339307: find ~/ -mtime $(echo $(date +%s) - $(date +%s -d"Dec 31, 2009 23:59:59") | bc -l | awk '{print $1 / 86400}' | bc -l)

find . -mtime $(date +%s -d"Aug 10, 2013 23:59:59") -mtime $(date +%s -d"Aug 1, 2013 23:59:59")

Top-3 Scripts:
so_16757326: tmp=$(mktemp /tmp/time-XXXXXXXX)
touch -t 200801010000 "$tmp"
find . -type f -iname '*.pdf' -newer "$tmp"
rm "$tmp"

Explanations about Options.-t:
STAMP
 use [[CC]YY]MMDDhhmm[.ss] instead of current time

Explanations about Options.-mtime:
File's data was last modified n*24 hours ago. See the comments for -atime to
 understand how rounding affects the interpretation of file modification times.
Explanations about Options.-iname:
Like -name, but the match is case insensitive. For example, the patterns `fo*' and
 `F??' match the file names `Foo', `FOO', `foo', `fOo', etc. The pattern `*foo*`
 will also match a file called '.foobar'.
Explanations about Options.-print0:
Always print the exact filename, unchanged, even if the output is going to a
 terminal.

su_1598430: Date, find out the number of days in a month
so_16858013: sort files found by command 'find'
Top-3 Scripts:
su_1598430: month=$(date +%m)
maxDayThisMonth=$(( for d in {00..31}; do date -d "+$d days" +%m-%d ; done ; ) | grep -Po "(?<=$month-)\d+" | sort -rn | head -1)

nextMonth=$(printf "%02d" $(( ($month+1) % 12 )) )
maxDayNextMonth=$(( for d in {01..62}; do date -d "+$d days" +%m-%d ; done ; ) | grep -Po "(?<=$nextMonth-)\d+" | sort -rn | head -1)
